question.title: Can Spring Data JPA Entity Manager createQuery() return an interface?
question.body:
I am trying to return an interface from a call to createQuery(). It fails when trying to create the query with

org.hibernate.query.QueryTypeMismatchException: Result type 'DcListInterface' cannot be used to package the selected expressions

The same query works when defined with @Query on a JPA repository, so I know the interface matches the query.

Can EntityManager's createQuery() return a proxy of the interface or is this functionality that is available only on a repository that extends one of the JPA repositories?

JPA based repo:

public interface DcRepository extends JpaRepository<DcMotor, Long> {
@Query("select dc.id, dc.manufacturer from DcMotor dc ")
List<DcListInterface> testQuery();
}

Successful test using JPA repository

@Test
void givenRepository_whenTest_thenSuccess() {
    assertThat(dcRepository).isNotNull();
    List<DcListInterface> dcListInterface = dcRepository.testQuery();
    assertThat(dcListInterface).isNotNull();
}

Failing test using the EntityManger directly without JPA repository

@Test
@Transactional(readOnly = true)
void test() {
    TypedQuery<DcListInterface> query = em.createQuery("select dc.id, dc.manufacturer from DcMotor dc ", DcListInterface.class);
// org.hibernate.query.QueryTypeMismatchException thrown on above line.
    List<DcListInterface> result = query.getResultList();
    assertThat(result).isNotNull();
}

answers.body:
Can Spring Data JPA Entity Manager createQuery() return an interface?

Trivially, yes. <T>EntityManager.createQuery(String, Class<T>) returns TypedQuery<T>, and TypedQuery is an interface.

I think you actually meant to ask whether the method's type argument can be an interface type. Also yes. The API docs already linked require of the type argument only that the result type of the query be assignable to it.

But, per the docs,

  • the query's select list must consist of a single item, and
  • that item's type must be assignable to the chosen type

Your query has two items in its select list, so it is not suitable for the createQuery() method invoked by your example code.

It's not clear what DcListInterface is supposed to represent. If you mean it to be a list of all the results then that's just not how the API works. But if you mean it to correspond to each individual result, and if com.my.DcList is a concrete class that implements that interface and has a suitable constructor, then this would work:

TypedQuery<DcListInterface> query = em.createQuery(
    "select new com.my.DcList(dc.id, dc.manufacturer) from DcMotor dc",
    DcListInterface.class);

But given the need to use a constructor expression to convert your multiple individual entity properties into a single item, you cannot get away without providing and a concrete class for the elements and naming it in the query.

I had to read a bit of documentation before answering this, I'll keep it clear and simple:

The Core Issue:

- Spring Data JPA automatically generates proxy objects for interfaces in repository queries.

- EntityManager.createQuery() does not support proxies for interfaces, leading to the QueryTypeMismatchException Exception.

Why is this?

When using: EntityManager.createQuery() , Hibernate expects the result type to be an entity or a concrete class(DTO). Since in your case, DcListInterface is an interface, Hibernate can't create it, leading to that error.

On the other hand, Spring Data JPA supports interface-based projections, meaning you can define a repository method, like the one in you question.

Suggestions:

  1. If you want to use: EntityManager.createQuery(), set a DTO instead of an interface if the change won't affect your code logic. Here is a basic example:

public class DcListDTO {
    private Long id;
    private String manufacturer;

    public DcListDTO(Long id, String manufacturer) {
        this.id = id;
        this.manufacturer = manufacturer;
    }

    // Getters and setters
}

2. Stick to Spring Data JPA Repository: this way, interface-based projections are handled automatically, so it is a valid approach for what you are trying to achieve.

To summarize, Spring Data JPA supports interface-based projections, while Hibernate’s EntityManager.createQuery() does not, as it requires a concrete class. If you need interface-based projections, stick to Spring Data JPA repository methods, or switch to a DTO when using EntityManager.createQuery().

Here is an interesting documentation about JPA Query Methods: https://docs.spring.io/spring-data/jpa/reference/jpa/query-methods.html. I haven't read much of it, but it seems like it covers different ways to create queries in Spring Data JPA.

79613100.body: Appreciate the research you did and providing confirmation that the "magic" for interfaces happens in Spring JPA.  Unfortunately the full code is way more involved and doesn't lend itself to standard JPA repository without the use of Criteria API and that is too convoluted to use.
